name: Spaghetti Bolognese
instructions:
1. Bring a large pot of salted water to the boil for the pasta.

2. Heat olive oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add onion and sauté for about 5 minutes until soft and translucent.

3. Add the garlic and cook for another minute until fragrant.

4. Increase heat to medium-high and add the ground beef. Break it up with a wooden spoon and cook until browned and no pink remains, about 5-7 minutes.

5. Pour in the red wine and simmer for 2-3 minutes, allowing the alcohol to evaporate.

6. Add the crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, dried oregano, dried basil, beef stock, and bay leaf. Stir well.

7. Season with salt and pepper, then reduce heat to low. Simmer uncovered for 25-30 minutes, stirring occasionally until the sauce thickens.

8. While the sauce is simmering, cook the spaghetti according to package instructions until al dente, usually 8-10 minutes.

9. Drain the pasta, reserving a small cup of pasta water.

10. Remove the bay leaf from the sauce. If the sauce is too thick, add a splash of reserved pasta water.

11. Serve the spaghetti topped with the Bolognese sauce, a sprinkle of grated Parmesan cheese, and fresh parsley.
notes: For authentic Bolognese, use a mixture of ground beef and pork for enhanced flavor. The sauce can be made ahead and stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days, or frozen for up to 3 months. The flavor actually improves the next day!

name: Chicken Curry
instructions:
1. In a bowl, season the diced chicken with salt and pepper and set aside.

2. Heat vegetable oil in a large, deep pan or pot over medium heat.

3. Add onions and sauté until soft and translucent, about 4-5 minutes.

4. Add garlic and ginger, cooking for another 1-2 minutes until fragrant.

5. Add all the dry spices (curry powder, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and cayenne pepper) and stir continuously for 30 seconds to toast the spices without burning them.

6. Add the chicken to the pan and cook until it's no longer pink and starts to brown slightly, about 5-7 minutes.

7. Add the diced tomatoes and cook for 2-3 minutes until they begin to break down.

8. Pour in the coconut milk and chicken stock, stirring well to combine.

9. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low. Cover and cook for about 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally.

10. Remove the lid and simmer for an additional 5 minutes to thicken the sauce if needed.

11. Taste and adjust seasoning with salt and pepper.

12. Stir in fresh lime juice just before serving.

13. Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve with basmati rice or naan bread.
notes: For a spicier curry, add a finely chopped green chili with the garlic and ginger. For a creamier texture, use full-fat coconut milk. This curry tastes even better the next day after the flavors have had time to meld.

name: Beef Stroganoff

ingredients.name: beef sirloin or ribeye, thinly sliced

instructions:
1. In a bowl, combine flour, salt, pepper, and paprika. Toss the beef slices in this mixture until lightly coated.

2. In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of butter and the oil over high heat. Once hot, add the beef in a single layer (work in batches if necessary) and quickly sear on both sides until browned but not fully cooked, about 1 minute per side. Transfer to a plate.

3. In the same skillet, add another tablespoon of butter. Add mushrooms and cook until they release their moisture and begin to brown, about 5 minutes. Transfer to the plate with the beef.

4. Add the remaining butter to the skillet. Add onions and cook until softened, about 3-4 minutes. Add garlic and cook for another 30 seconds.

5. Pour in beef broth, scraping the bottom of the pan to release any browned bits. Bring to a simmer.

6. Stir in Dijon mustard and Worcestershire sauce. Return to a simmer and cook for about 5 minutes until slightly reduced.

7. Meanwhile, cook egg noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.

8. Reduce heat to low and stir in sour cream until well incorporated.

9. Return beef and mushrooms to the skillet, along with any accumulated juices. Simmer gently for 2-3 minutes until beef is cooked through and sauce is thickened. Be careful not to boil after adding the sour cream as it may curdle.

10. Serve over egg noodles and garnish with fresh parsley.
notes: For the most tender result, slice the beef against the grain and make sure the pan is very hot before searing. The sauce can be made in advance up to the point of adding the sour cream. When ready to serve, reheat gently and then add the sour cream. Traditional Russian Stroganoff uses a small amount of tomato paste, which you can add with the broth if desired.

name: Sourdough Bread
instructions:
1. In a large bowl, mix the sourdough starter with warm water until dissolved.

2. Add the flour and mix until you have a shaggy dough with no dry flour remaining.

3. Cover the bowl with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes (autolyse phase).

4. Add the salt and incorporate it by pinching and folding the dough.

5. Begin the bulk fermentation: perform a series of stretch and folds every 30 minutes for the first 2 hours. Simply grab one side of the dough, stretch it up, and fold it over to the other side. Rotate the bowl 90 degrees and repeat for all four sides.

6. Let the dough rise at room temperature (around 75°F/24°C) for another 2-4 hours until it has increased in volume by about 50% and shows bubbles on the surface.

7. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. Shape it into a round by pulling the edges into the center to create tension on the surface.

8. Let it rest for 15 minutes, then shape it again into a tight boule or batard shape.

9. Transfer the dough, seam-side up, to a floured banneton or a bowl lined with a floured kitchen towel.

10. Cover and refrigerate for 12-15 hours (cold fermentation).

11. Preheat your oven to 500°F (260°C) with a Dutch oven inside for at least 45 minutes.

12. Turn the dough out onto a piece of parchment paper, score the top with a sharp knife or razor blade.

13. Carefully place the dough with the parchment into the hot Dutch oven, cover with the lid, and bake for 20 minutes.

14. Reduce the temperature to 450°F (230°C), remove the lid, and bake for another 20-25 minutes until the crust is deep golden brown.

15. Transfer to a wire rack and let cool completely for at least 2 hours before slicing.
notes: The key to great sourdough is patience and maintaining a healthy starter. The long fermentation develops flavor and creates the characteristic open crumb. For best results, use a kitchen scale to measure ingredients by weight. The bread keeps well for 4-5 days stored in a paper bag or wrapped in a cloth.

name: Berry Bliss Smoothie
instructions:
1. Add all ingredients to a high-speed blender.

2. Blend on high until smooth and creamy, about 60 seconds.

3. If the smoothie is too thick, add more almond milk. If it's too thin, add more frozen berries or ice.

4. Pour into glasses and serve immediately. Garnish with additional berries or mint leaves if desired.
notes: For a vegan version, use plant-based yogurt and maple syrup instead of honey. You can boost the nutrition by adding a handful of spinach—the berry flavor will mask it completely. For a protein-rich post-workout smoothie, add a scoop of your favorite protein powder.

name: Classic Mojito
instructions:
1. Place mint leaves and 1 lime wedge into a sturdy glass. Use a muddler to crush the mint and lime to release the mint oils and lime juice.

2. Add 2 more lime wedges and the sugar, and muddle again to release the lime juice. Do not strain the mixture.

3. Fill the glass almost to the top with ice. Pour the rum over the ice, and fill the glass with carbonated water.

4. Stir, taste, and add more sugar if desired. Garnish with the remaining lime wedge and additional mint leaves.
notes: The key to a great mojito is properly muddling the mint—you want to press just enough to release the oils without shredding the leaves. For a variation, try using different fruit like berries or watermelon, or substitute the sugar with simple syrup. For a non-alcoholic version, replace the rum with sparkling water or sprite.

name: French Onion Soup
instructions:
1. In a large Dutch oven or heavy-bottomed pot, melt the butter with olive oil over medium heat.

2. Add the sliced onions and cook, stirring occasionally, for about 10 minutes until they begin to soften and turn translucent.

3. Sprinkle with sugar (helps caramelization) and reduce heat to medium-low. Continue cooking the onions for about 40-50 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent burning, until they are deeply caramelized and a rich golden-brown color.

4. Add flour to the caramelized onions and stir continuously for about 2-3 minutes to cook the flour.

5. Gradually add the beef stock while stirring, then add the white wine, bay leaf, and thyme.

6. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low and simmer gently for about 30 minutes, allowing the soup to thicken slightly and the flavors to meld. Season with salt and pepper.

7. Meanwhile, preheat the broiler. Place baguette slices on a baking sheet and toast under the broiler until golden brown on both sides, about 1-2 minutes per side.

8. Ladle the soup into oven-safe bowls. Place the bowls on a baking sheet.

9. Float 1-2 toasted baguette slices on top of each bowl of soup, then sprinkle generously with grated Gruyère cheese.

10. Place under the broiler until the cheese is melted, bubbly, and slightly browned, about 2-3 minutes.

11. Carefully remove from oven (bowls will be very hot) and serve immediately.
notes: The secret to exceptional French onion soup is patience during the caramelization process—properly caramelized onions should take at least 40 minutes. For vegetarians, substitute beef stock with vegetable stock. Traditional French onion soup uses Gruyère, but you can substitute with Swiss cheese. For the best flavor, use homemade beef stock if possible.

name: Sous Vide Ribeye Steak
instructions:
1. Set the sous vide water bath to 129°F (54°C) for medium-rare. Adjust temperature based on your preferred doneness.

2. Season the ribeye steaks generously with salt and pepper on all sides.

3. Place each steak in a separate vacuum-seal bag or ziplock bag. Add crushed garlic cloves and herb sprigs to each bag.

4. Seal the bags using a vacuum sealer, or if using ziplock bags, use the water displacement method to remove the air before sealing.

5. Once the water bath reaches the target temperature, submerge the sealed bags in the water. Make sure the steaks are fully submerged.

6. Cook for 2 hours. The steaks can remain in the bath for up to 4 hours without any degradation in quality.

7. About 15 minutes before serving, prepare for searing. Heat a cast-iron skillet over high heat until smoking hot.

8. Remove the steaks from the bags and pat them completely dry with paper towels. This is crucial for a good sear.

9. Add the oil to the hot skillet. Once shimmering, carefully place the steaks in the skillet.

10. Sear for 45-60 seconds on each side, using tongs to turn them. Add butter, remaining garlic, and herbs to the pan, and baste the steaks continuously for about 30 seconds.

11. Remove the steaks from the pan and let them rest for 5 minutes before slicing.

12. Slice against the grain and serve immediately.
notes: The beauty of sous vide cooking is precision and consistency. Allow the steaks to come to room temperature before searing for the best results. For an even better crust, you can briefly chill the steaks in the freezer for 10 minutes after taking them out of the sous vide bath and before searing. The internal temperature of 129°F (54°C) will yield a perfect medium-rare steak from edge to edge.

name: Lobster Bisque
instructions:
1. Bring a large pot of heavily salted water to a rolling boil. Plunge the live lobsters headfirst into the water. Cover and cook for about 8 minutes. The shells should be bright red.

2. Remove lobsters and place in an ice bath to stop the cooking process. Once cool enough to handle, crack the shells and remove all meat from the tail, claws, and knuckles. Reserve the shells and bodies. Chop the meat into bite-sized pieces and refrigerate.

3. In a large Dutch oven or heavy pot, melt 4 tablespoons of butter over medium heat. Add the lobster shells and bodies, crushing them slightly with a wooden spoon. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 5-7 minutes until the shells turn a deeper red.

4. Add carrots, celery, onion, shallots, and garlic to the pot. Sauté for 5 minutes until vegetables begin to soften.

5. Add tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes, stirring constantly.

6. Sprinkle flour over the mixture and stir continuously for 2 minutes to cook the flour.

7. Add cognac and carefully ignite with a long match or lighter (stand back!) to burn off the alcohol. Once the flames subside, add white wine and simmer for 2-3 minutes.

8. Add fish stock, bay leaves, and thyme. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low and cook, partially covered, for 45 minutes.

9. Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve into a clean pot, pressing on the solids to extract all the flavor. Discard the solids.

10. Return the strained broth to medium heat and add the heavy cream. Simmer gently for 15 minutes to reduce and thicken slightly.

11. Season with cayenne pepper, paprika, salt, and white pepper to taste.

12. Just before serving, melt the remaining 2 tablespoons of butter in a skillet over medium heat. Add the reserved lobster meat and gently warm it through, being careful not to overcook.

13. Ladle the bisque into warmed bowls, place a portion of the lobster meat in the center of each bowl, and garnish with fresh chives.
notes: This Michelin-inspired lobster bisque relies on extracting maximum flavor from the lobster shells. For an even more luxurious presentation, reserve one of the claw pieces whole for garnish. The bisque can be made a day ahead (without adding the lobster meat) and gently reheated before serving. A splash of sherry can be added just before serving for an additional layer of flavor.

name: Cinnamon Rolls
instructions:
1. In a large mixing bowl, combine 2 cups of flour, sugar, yeast, and salt.

2. In a small saucepan, heat milk and 1/3 cup butter until very warm (120-130°F). The butter won't completely melt.

3. Add warm milk mixture and eggs to the flour mixture. Beat on medium speed for 2 minutes.

4. Stir in enough remaining flour to form a soft dough (it will be slightly sticky).

5. Turn onto a floured surface and knead until smooth and elastic, about 6-8 minutes.

6. Place in a greased bowl, turning once to grease the top. Cover and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size, about 1 hour.

7. Punch down the dough. On a lightly floured surface, roll into a 16x10-inch rectangle.

8. In a small bowl, mix brown sugar and cinnamon. Spread 1/4 cup softened butter over the dough, leaving a 1/2-inch border. Sprinkle evenly with the cinnamon-sugar mixture.

9. Starting with the long side, roll up tightly, pinching the seam to seal. Cut into 12 equal pieces.

10. Place rolls, cut side down, in a greased 13x9-inch baking pan. Cover and let rise until doubled, about 30-45 minutes.

11. Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).

12. Bake for 25-30 minutes until golden brown.

13. For the frosting, beat cream cheese and butter until fluffy. Beat in powdered sugar, vanilla, and salt until smooth.

14. Spread frosting over warm rolls. Serve warm.
notes: For overnight cinnamon rolls, prepare through step 10, then cover and refrigerate for up to 12 hours. Let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes before baking. For extra fluffy rolls, let the dough rise a bit longer. The rolls are best served warm but will keep for 2-3 days in an airtight container.

name: Green Detox Smoothie
instructions:
1. Add spinach, kale, green apple, cucumber, celery, ginger, and lemon juice to a high-speed blender.

2. Pour in the coconut water and blend on high speed until smooth.

3. Add the avocado, ice cubes, and hemp seeds. Blend again until creamy and smooth.

4. Taste and add honey or maple syrup if desired, blending briefly to incorporate.

5. Pour into glasses and serve immediately.
notes: This nutrient-dense smoothie is perfect for a morning cleanse or a post-workout recovery. The avocado adds healthy fats and creates a creamy texture. To meal-prep, you can freeze the fruits and vegetables in individual portions (except avocado) and blend with liquid when ready to consume. Add a scoop of plant-based protein powder to make it more filling.

name: Espresso Martini
instructions:
1. Fill a cocktail shaker with ice.

2. Add vodka, coffee liqueur, cooled espresso, and simple syrup.

3. Shake vigorously for at least 30 seconds—this is crucial for creating the characteristic foam.

4. Strain into a chilled martini glass.

5. Garnish with three coffee beans placed in the center of the foam.
notes: For the best foam, make sure all ingredients are well-chilled and shake longer than you think necessary. Fresh espresso creates a better flavor than instant coffee. For a non-alcoholic version, use alcohol-free coffee liqueur and replace vodka with cold brew concentrate. The three coffee beans are traditionally said to represent health, wealth, and happiness.

name: Butternut Squash Soup
instructions:
1. In a bowl, season the diced chicken with salt and pepper and set aside.

2. Heat vegetable oil in a large, deep pan or pot over medium heat.

3. Add onions and sauté until soft and translucent, about 4-5 minutes.

4. Add garlic and ginger, cooking for another 1-2 minutes until fragrant.

5. Add all the dry spices (curry powder, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and cayenne pepper) and stir continuously for 30 seconds to toast the spices without burning them.

6. Add the chicken to the pan and cook until it's no longer pink and starts to brown slightly, about 5-7 minutes.

7. Add the diced tomatoes and cook for 2-3 minutes until they begin to break down.

8. Pour in the coconut milk and chicken stock, stirring well to combine.

9. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low. Cover and cook for about 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally.

10. Remove the lid and simmer for an additional 5 minutes to thicken the sauce if needed.

11. Taste and adjust seasoning with salt and pepper.

12. Stir in fresh lime juice just before serving.

13. Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve with basmati rice or naan bread.
notes: For a spicier curry, add a finely chopped green chili with the garlic and ginger. For a creamier texture, use full-fat coconut milk. This curry tastes even better the next day after the flavors have had time to meld.

name: Caesar Salad
instructions:
1. For the chicken: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Rub chicken breast with olive oil, then season with garlic powder, salt, and pepper. Place on a baking sheet and roast for 20-25 minutes until internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C). Let cool, then slice into strips.

2. For the homemade Caesar dressing: In a medium bowl, whisk together egg yolks, minced garlic, Dijon mustard, anchovy fillets (if using), lemon juice, and Worcestershire sauce until well combined.

3. Very slowly drizzle in the olive oil while continuously whisking to create an emulsion. Season with salt and pepper to taste. If the dressing is too thick, add a teaspoon of water to thin it.

4. Tear or chop the romaine lettuce into bite-sized pieces, wash thoroughly, and dry completely with a salad spinner or paper towels.

5. In a large bowl, toss the romaine lettuce with about 3/4 of the dressing, making sure all leaves are lightly coated.

6. Add half the Parmesan cheese and toss again.

7. Transfer to serving plates and top with sliced chicken, croutons, and remaining Parmesan cheese.

8. Drizzle with remaining dressing and finish with a few grinds of fresh black pepper.
notes: For a traditional Caesar, use homemade dressing with raw egg yolks (or pasteurized if concerned about food safety). For a vegetarian version, omit the chicken and anchovies and use vegetarian Worcestershire sauce. Traditional Caesar salad doesn't actually contain chicken, but it's a popular protein addition.

name: Vegetable Stir-Fry
instructions:
1. Prepare all vegetables before starting to cook, as stir-frying is a quick process. Arrange them in order of cooking time: harder vegetables (carrots, broccoli) first, softer ones (zucchini, mushrooms) later.

2. In a small bowl, whisk together soy sauce, oyster sauce, rice vinegar, and brown sugar. In another small bowl, mix cornstarch with water to create a slurry.

3. Heat a wok or large skillet over high heat until very hot. Add vegetable oil and swirl to coat the surface.

4. Add garlic and ginger, stir-frying for about 30 seconds until fragrant but not browned.

5. Add carrots and broccoli, stir-frying for 2 minutes.

6. Add bell peppers and snow peas, continuing to stir-fry for another 2 minutes.

7. Add zucchini, mushrooms, baby corn, and water chestnuts. Stir-fry for an additional 2-3 minutes until vegetables are crisp-tender.

8. Pour in the sauce mixture and toss to coat all vegetables.

9. Add the cornstarch slurry and stir immediately to thicken the sauce, about 30 seconds.

10. Remove from heat and stir in sesame oil and most of the green onions (reserve some for garnish).

11. Transfer to a serving dish and garnish with remaining green onions, red pepper flakes, and toasted sesame seeds.

12. Serve immediately with steamed rice or noodles.
notes: For protein, add tofu, tempeh, chicken, beef, or shrimp (add at the beginning after garlic and ginger). The key to a good stir-fry is having all ingredients prepared before you start cooking and using high heat. Don't overcrowd the pan - cook in batches if necessary.

name: Pancakes

ingredients.name: vegetable oil or butter for cooking

instructions:
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

2. In a separate bowl, whisk together the buttermilk, eggs, melted butter, and vanilla extract until well combined.

3. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir gently with a spatula until just combined. Some small lumps are fine - do not overmix or pancakes will be tough.

4. Let the batter rest for 5-10 minutes to allow the leavening agents to activate and the gluten to relax.

5. Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat. Add a small amount of oil or butter to lightly coat the surface.

6. For each pancake, pour about 1/4 cup of batter onto the skillet. Cook until bubbles form on the surface and the edges look set, about 2-3 minutes.

7. Flip and cook the other side until golden brown, about 1-2 minutes more.

8. Transfer to a plate and cover loosely with foil to keep warm while cooking the remaining pancakes.

9. Serve immediately with maple syrup, fresh berries, and whipped cream if desired.
notes: If you don't have buttermilk, make a substitute by adding 1 tablespoon of lemon juice or white vinegar to regular milk and letting it sit for 5 minutes. For flavor variations, add chocolate chips, blueberries, sliced bananas, or chopped nuts to the batter. The pancakes can be kept warm in a 200°F (95°C) oven while cooking the full batch.

name: Guacamole
instructions:
1. Cut the avocados in half, remove the pits, and scoop the flesh into a medium bowl.

2. Add the lime juice and mash the avocados with a fork until you reach your desired consistency (some prefer chunky, others smooth).

3. Fold in the red onion, jalapeño, garlic, cilantro, and tomato.

4. Season with cumin, salt, and pepper. Taste and adjust seasonings as needed.

5. If not serving immediately, press plastic wrap directly on the surface of the guacamole to prevent browning and refrigerate for up to 2 hours.
notes: The pit doesn't actually prevent browning - that's a myth. Lime juice and plastic wrap directly on the surface are your best bets. For a spicier guacamole, leave some jalapeño seeds in or add a dash of hot sauce. For the best flavor, use ripe avocados that yield slightly to gentle pressure.

name: Mushroom Risotto
instructions:
1. Place dried porcini mushrooms in a small bowl and cover with hot water. Let soak for 20 minutes. Once soft, remove mushrooms, finely chop them, and strain the soaking liquid through a fine sieve to remove any grit. Reserve both the mushrooms and liquid.

2. In a large, wide saucepan, heat 1 tablespoon of butter and 1 tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat. Add the fresh mushrooms and cook until golden brown and their liquid has evaporated, about 8-10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Remove two-thirds of the mushrooms and set aside.

3. In the same pan, add the remaining olive oil. Add the onion and cook until soft and translucent, about 4-5 minutes. Add the garlic and thyme, cooking for another minute.

4. Add the rice and stir to coat with oil, toasting it for about 2 minutes until the edges become translucent.

5. Pour in the wine and stir until almost completely absorbed.

6. Add the chopped porcini mushrooms and a ladleful of the warm stock to the rice. Stir constantly until the liquid is almost completely absorbed.

7. Continue adding stock, one ladleful at a time, stirring frequently and allowing each addition to be absorbed before adding more. This process takes about 18-20 minutes.

8. After about 15 minutes, add the reserved porcini liquid.

9. Test the rice regularly towards the end of cooking. It should be creamy but still have a slight bite to it (al dente).

10. Once the rice is cooked, remove from heat. Stir in the remaining butter, Parmesan cheese, and the reserved cooked mushrooms.

11. Cover and let rest for 2 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.

12. Serve immediately, garnished with fresh parsley and additional Parmesan cheese if desired.
notes: The key to perfect risotto is adding the stock gradually and stirring frequently to release the rice's starch for a creamy texture. Don't rush the process. For a vegan version, use olive oil instead of butter and nutritional yeast instead of Parmesan. For an elevated presentation, add a drizzle of truffle oil just before serving.

name: Chocolate Chip Cookies
instructions:
1. Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.

2. In a small bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.

3. In a large bowl, beat the softened butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar with an electric mixer on medium speed until creamy, about 2-3 minutes.

4. Add vanilla extract and eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition.

5. Gradually add the flour mixture to the butter mixture, beating on low speed until just combined. Do not overmix.

6. Stir in chocolate chips and nuts (if using) with a wooden spoon or spatula.

7. Drop rounded tablespoons of dough about 2 inches apart onto the prepared baking sheets.

8. Bake for 9-11 minutes or until golden brown around the edges but still soft in the center.

9. Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.

10. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 5 days.
notes: For chewier cookies, use more brown sugar than white sugar. For a softer texture, add an extra egg yolk. Chilling the dough for at least 30 minutes (or up to 72 hours) before baking will enhance flavor and prevent spreading. For an extra touch, sprinkle a little flaky sea salt on top just before baking.
